ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Right Horizontal (Lateral) Canalithiasis
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Supine roll testing showed geotropic nystagmus stronger on the right side (135 deg/s vs 50 deg/s); Bow and Lean Test showed right-beating nystagmus in the bow position, confirming the right ear as the affected side.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Left Horizontal (Lateral) Canalithiasis
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Initially suspected by the referring physician due to history, but ruled out by the intensity of nystagmus (stronger on right) and the direction of the Bow and Lean Test results.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Posterior Canal BPPV
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Ruled out during the current presentation as the nystagmus was purely horizontal without the torsional component seen in the patient's previous episode 2 years prior.

ordered_list.rationale_short: Initial assessment performed 2 years prior for vertigo triggered by head movement.
Bedside assessment of recurrent vertigo symptoms at the physician's office.
Part of the formal vestibular battery to assess for central or peripheral vestibular dysfunction.
To identify the specific canal and side involved in BPPV using video goggles for precise measurement.
To differentiate the affected ear in lateral canal BPPV when roll test lateralization is ambiguous or to confirm findings.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Two years prior, the patient presented with vertigo. Testing revealed Left Posterior Canal BPPV, which was successfully treated with an Epley maneuver.

tests.name: Dix-Hallpike / Positional Testing
tests.result_summary: Brisk upbeat geotropic torsional nystagmus in head-hanging left position; duration 15-20 seconds after 2-3 second latency.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The patient returned with recurrent vertigo. Clinical examination showed horizontal nystagmus consistent with lateral canal BPPV. Although eye movements appeared stronger on the right, the physician treated the left side based on history, which worsened symptoms.

tests.name: Positional Testing (Clinical)
tests.result_summary: Left Dix-Hallpike elicited brisk geotropic horizontal nystagmus. Roll test showed stronger eye movement on the right side.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Formal vestibular testing confirmed Right Horizontal Canalithiasis. Positional testing showed geotropic nystagmus stronger on the right side (135 deg/s vs 50 deg/s). The Bow and Lean Test confirmed the right side as affected (Bow right, Lean left).

tests.name: VNG/VOG - Spontaneous & Gaze
tests.result_summary: 1 deg/s rightward-beating spontaneous nystagmus without vision; no gaze nystagmus.

tests.name: Positional Testing (Dix-Hallpike & Supine Roll)
tests.result_summary: Robust geotropic horizontal nystagmus in lateral positions. Stronger in Supine Body Right (135 deg/s) compared to Supine Body Left (50 deg/s).

tests.name: Bow and Lean Test (BLT)
tests.result_summary: Bow position: 97 deg/s rightward nystagmus. Lean position: 65 deg/s leftward nystagmus. Indicates right ear affected.

proposed_items: 360-degree log roll maneuver from right to left
counseling_actions: Sleep on left side with head propped up slightly to avoid recurrence

escalation.rationale_short: Patient was treated successfully in the clinic and instructed to return only if symptoms recur.

expected_outcome: Patient remains symptom-free for 20 months to date.
